description: Borrowed from Ancient Greek παράφερνα (parápherna, “goods which a wife brings over and above her dowry”), a compound of παρά (pará, “beside”) +‎ φερνή (phernḗ, “dowry”). In the propertied classes, a dowry was placed under the control of the husband, while the paraphernalia which she brought with her remained the wife’s property.

entries.meaning: Miscellaneous items, especially the set of equipment required for a particular activity.
examples: He has an impressive collection of bicycling paraphernalia, but he doesn't ride very often anymore.

entries.meaning: (archaic, family law) Things a married woman owns, such as clothing and jewellery, apart from her dowry.
